 | subdivmap = subdivs = # County Durham (Unitary)
 # Hartlepool (Unitary) Darlington (Unitary) Stockton-on-Tees (Unitary)
 # *
* Only the part of the borough to the north of the River Tees is within
the ceremonial County Durham. }} 'County Durham' (, locally ) is a
ceremonial county and (smaller) unitary district in North
East England. The county town is Durham. The largest settlement in the
ceremonial county (in its own unitary borough) is Darlington. John Marius Wilson, [http://www.visionofbritain.org.uk/descriptio-
ns/entry_page.jsp?text_id=805350&word=NULL Durham], Imperial Gazetteer of
England and Wales, (1870-72). Retrieved 30 November 2007. The county has a
mixture of mining and farming heritage, as well as a heavy railway industry,
particularly in the southeast of the county in Darlington, Shildon and Stockton.
Its economy was historically based on coal and iron mining. Durham County Council - [http://www.durham.gov.uk/durhamcc/usp.nsf/pws/History+and+heritage+-
+History+and+heritage+of+county+durham History and Heritage of County Durham].
Retrieved 30 November 2007. It is an area of regeneration and promoted as
a tourist destination.

The ceremonial county borders Tyne and Wear, Cumbria, Northumberland and North
Yorkshire, forming part of the North East England region. North East Assembly -
[http://www.northeastassembly.gov.uk/page.asp?id=348 About North East England].
Retrieved 30 November 2007.
categories: Local government districts of North East England
